awd_titl_txt: STEM at the Poles! Research Experiences for Formal and Informal Educations in the Polar Regions
awd_abstract_narration:
The Arctic Research Consortium (ARCUS) of the U.S. will administer and implement "STEM at the Poles", a program that provides opportunities for U.S. educators to participate in cutting-edge field research with polar scientists in various, and often remote, locations in the Arctic and Antarctica. During this three-year project, thirty-six participants from the field of education, including eighteen U.S. middle and high school teachers and eighteen U.S. informal science educators (e.g. educators who work outside classrooms and who work with the public or middle and high school students and/or their teachers), will participate in a research experience with scientists in the Arctic and Antarctic. Through this unique experience, ARCUS will provide a professional development opportunity for both formal and informal educators where they will: (1) connect to the polar regions and the research community; (2) develop Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics (STEM) resources that help advance the basic knowledge of polar regions across a variety of learning environments; and (3) change how they teach STEM in both informal and formal learning environments. The program will provide numerous opportunities for students and the public to learn about how polar research is conducted both in the Arctic and Antarctic and will help polar researchers learn to communicate more effectively with students and the public.

Specifically, the goals of the program are as follows: (1) Improve educators' STEM content knowledge of the Polar Regions and the science conducted in these regions; (2) Increase educators' knowledge and use of STEM practices with their students in their learning setting; (3) Build educators' STEM identity; (4) Increase the STEM collaborations between formal and informal educators; (5) Increase students' understanding and engagement in the polar regions and interest in polar-related STEM careers; and (6) Develop long-term professional relationships between the education and research communities.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
For over two decades, PolarTREC-Teachers and Researchers Exploring and Collaborating (https://www.polartrec.com), has been bridging the gap between educators and researchers in polar science expeditions in the Arctic and Antarctica. This transformative initiative facilitated countless collaborations, forged powerful connections between educators and scientists, and ignited a passion for scientific understanding. As of 31 May 2023, PolarTREC, administered by the Arctic Research Consortium of the US (ARCUS) has officially ended.

The program's primary goals were to enhance science education by connecting teachers with cutting-edge research and to promote science literacy by fostering a deeper understanding of polar science and its relevance to global environmental issues. Teachers who participate in PolarTREC brought back their experiences back to their classrooms, incorporating real-world research into their curriculum and inspiring students to explore STEM (science, technology, engineering, and mathematics) fields.

The PolarTREC program has yielded several significant outcomes since its inception:

  1. Enhanced Science Education: PolarTREC has enriched science education by providing teachers with hands-on experiences in polar research. Teachers bring this real-world knowledge back to their classrooms, creating engaging lessons that incorporate authentic scientific methods and discoveries.
  2. Inspired Students: By integrating actual polar research into their teaching, PolarTREC teachers inspire students to become more interested in STEM subjects. Students gain a better understanding of complex scientific concepts and are motivated to pursue careers in science-related fields.
  3. Teacher Professional Development: The program offers professional development opportunities for educators, enabling them to deepen their knowledge of current research, technology, and data analysis techniques. This strengthens their teaching skills and benefits their professional growth.
  4. Science Communication: PolarTREC enhances science communication by encouraging scientists and teachers to collaborate on research projects. This collaboration fosters effective communication of scientific findings to the broader public, promoting a better understanding of polar science and its relevance.
  5. Diverse Perspectives: The program promotes diversity and inclusion by involving teachers from various backgrounds, which in turn leads to the representation of diverse voices in polar research and education.
  6. Long-Term Impact: Many PolarTREC participants continue to apply their experiences and knowledge beyond the program. They develop innovative teaching materials, engage in community outreach, and contribute to ongoing research efforts.
  7. Research Collaboration: Scientists benefit from the program by gaining assistance from teachers in the field, thus increasing their capacity for data collection and research activities. This collaboration also aids in disseminating research findings to wider audiences. Researchers continue to network and collaborate with educators long after the initial field experience.
  8. Global Awareness: PolarTREC increases awareness of the polar regions and the impacts of climate change on these areas. Through their experiences, teachers and students become more informed about environmental issues and contribute to ongoing discussions about polar science.

In summary, PolarTREC has generated positive outcomes by enhancing science education, inspiring students, fostering science communication, promoting diversity, and creating lasting impacts on both teachers and researchers. The program's collaborative approach has contributed to a broader understanding of polar science and its implications for the world.

In celebration of the program, a video has been created featuring over 20 years of PolarTREC. The PolarTREC team invites you to view it on YouTube (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vyavDtTpHQs). We hope that you enjoy it as you witness firsthand the immersive experiences and educational opportunities created by the program. You can continue to stay informed about polar education news through the ARCUS website (www.arcus.org), social media and email lists. Reach out to us at education@arcus.org.
